title: Brazen Attack Near Moscow Rattles Russians
abstract: The daughter of a prominent ultranationalist, herself a hawkish commentator, was killed by a car bomb deep in Russian territory.

multimedia.caption: A photo provided by the Russian government shows investigators at the site of a car bombing outside Moscow that killed a political commentator.

title: What Russians See in the News: A War Over Western Plans to Subjugate Them
abstract: In the Kremlin-controlled news media, the war is not about Ukraine, but about a long history of enemies trying to keep Russia down.

multimedia.caption: The Echo of Moscow studio in March, just before the media outlet was shut down and its radio frequency taken over by Radio Sputnik, which broadcasts Kremlin propaganda. Now, the Russian news media landscape is almost entirely government-controlled.
multimedia.copyright: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times

title: ‘Artistic Awakening’ in Benin as Return of Royal Artifacts Attracts Huge Crowds
abstract: As more looted art comes back to Africa, countries have wrestled with the right way to display it. That 200,000 people have lined up for a show suggests Benin has found an answer.

multimedia.caption: Euloge Ahanhanzo Glèlè, a sculptor in Benin, in front of the throne of his ancestor King Glélé at an exhibition of looted artifacts recently returned to the country.
multimedia.copyright: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Euloge Ahanhanzo Glèlè, a sculptor in Benin, in front of the throne of his ancestor King Glélé at an exhibition of looted artifacts recently returned to the country.

title: Former Pakistan Prime Minister Charged Under Terrorism Act
abstract: The move against Imran Khan is a major escalation of the power struggle between the government and the former leader and risks renewed public unrest.
byline: By Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum

title: The Face of China: A Globetrotting Diplomat Armed With U.S. Admonitions
abstract: While Xi Jinping hasn’t visited another country in the pandemic, his foreign minister, Wang Yi, has been to dozens, extolling Beijing’s vision for the world.

multimedia.caption: Wang Yi, China’s foreign minister, at a Group of 20 meeting in Bali, Indonesia, last month. He has been to more than 30 countries this year.
multimedia.copyright: Pool photo by Stefani Reynolds

title: Singapore to Repeal Ban on Sex Between Consenting Men
abstract: In announcing the move, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong took a step long sought by gay rights advocates, but he said same-sex marriage would continue to be illegal.
des_facet: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

multimedia.caption: A Pink Dot event in Singapore in 2019. The annual event is the closest thing the country has to a gay pride parade.

title: U.S. Delegation Visits Taiwan for Trade Talks, Risking China’s Ire
abstract: Gov. Eric J. Holcomb of Indiana led a group that arrived on the island Sunday, even as visits this month by U.S. officials have angered Beijing.
byline: By Isabella Kwai and Amy Chang Chien

multimedia.caption: Gov. Eric J. Holcomb of Indiana and his delegation will meet with President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan and representatives of the island’s semiconductor industries during a four-day visit.
multimedia.copyright: Darron Cummings/Associated Press

title: Economic Neglect and Political Instability Unraveled Tunisia’s Democracy
abstract: Tensions across the religious-secular fault lines in the country could not be reconciled, and freely elected leaders failed to deliver on the 2011 uprising’s cry for bread, freedom and dignity.
des_facet: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

multimedia.caption: Shopping for secondhand clothing at a market in Kairouan, in northern Tunisia, with a poster of President Kais Saied adorning a building in the background.

title: Shabab Attack on Somali Hotel Ends With 21 Dead, Officials Say
abstract: The assault was the most sustained and complex in the capital, Mogadishu, since a new president was elected in May. Officials said more than 100 were wounded.

multimedia.caption: The Hayat Hotel in Mogadishu, Somalia, on Sunday. The siege underscored how the Shabab continue to pose a threat to the country’s stability.
multimedia.copyright: Hassan Ali Elmi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

multimedia.caption: The Hayat Hotel in Mogadishu, Somalia, on Sunday. The siege underscored how the Shabab continue to pose a threat to the country’s stability.

title: Odesa Is Defiant. It’s Also Putin’s Ultimate Target.
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin knows that Ukraine’s fate, its access to the sea and its grain exports hinge on Odesa. Without it, the country shrivels to a landlocked rump state.
byline: By Roger Cohen and Laetitia Vancon

multimedia.caption: Odesa Is Defiant. It’s Also Putin’s Ultimate Target.
Odesa Is Defiant. It’s Also Putin’s Ultimate Target.
Odesa Is Defiant. It’s Also Putin’s Ultimate Target.

title: In India, New Wave of Trauma as 11 Convicted of Rape and Murder Walk Free
abstract: Just as Bilkis Bano had started to rebuild her life after grisly communal violence in 2002, a state government cut short her assailants’ life sentences.
byline: By Karan Deep Singh, Suhasini Raj and Mujib Mashal

title: Ethiopian Airlines Pilots Miss Landing After Reportedly Falling Asleep
abstract: The pilots reportedly could not be reached by air traffic control and were woken by an onboard alarm. The airline said they have been suspended pending an investigation.

title: Dairy Farmers in the Netherlands Are Up in Arms Over Emission Cuts
abstract: Goals of cutting nitrogen emissions in half by 2030 have caused an uproar in the Netherlands. Climate activists say the cuts are necessary to preserve nature.

multimedia.caption: “My livelihood and my network is being threatened,” said Ben Apeldoorn, who has been farming for 30 years.

title: Hungary’s Orban, a Scourge of Liberals, Faces a New Foe: Economics
abstract: The Hungarian leader is being confronted with soaring inflation and a depreciating currency linked to unsustainable spending by his government.
byline: By Andrew Higgins and Benjamin Novak

multimedia.caption: Demonstrations on Wednesday in Budapest against a decree that would allow some trees to be cut to give Hungarians access to cheap firewood.

title: A Teen’s Journey Into the Internet’s Darkness and Back Again
abstract: As anxiety and depression soar among adolescents, researchers struggle to understand how exactly social media affects mental health.
byline: By Matt Richtel and Annie Flanagan

multimedia.caption: “I feel like if I was born in 2000 B.C. in the Alps, I’d still be depressive, but I think it’s wildly exacerbated by the climate we live in,” said C, who is 22 and lives in Salt Lake City.

title: The Question Menacing Brazil’s Elections: Coup or No Coup?
abstract: President Bolsonaro has warned of voter fraud and suggested he would dispute a loss in October’s vote, but the political establishment believes he lacks support to stage a coup.
byline: By Jack Nicas and André Spigariol
des_facet: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

multimedia.caption: President Jair Bolsonaro greeting supporters last month in Salvador, Brazil. Mr. Bolsonaro has consistently attacked voting machines in the country as susceptible to fraud, leading to questions about his willingness to accept an election loss.

title: Bolsonaro Grabs for Man’s Phone and Gets a New (Insulting) Nickname
abstract: Six weeks ahead of national elections, the Brazilian president was confronted by a protester who tried to ask questions on video. He grabbed the man’s shirt, then tried to snatch his phone.

title: Mexico Arrests Top Prosecutor in Case of Missing Students and Issues 80 Warrants
abstract: The country’s former attorney general, accused of covering up the probable massacre of 43 students, was charged with forced disappearance, torture and obstruction of justice.

title: Crypto Is Tumbling, but in Argentina It’s Still a Safer Bet
abstract: Even though cryptocurrencies have lost value, many Argentines see them as a less risky choice than their own currency, whose worth has plunged as inflation has soared.

title: Vadim V. Bakatin, the Last Chairman of the K.G.B., Dies at 84
abstract: He led the spy agency for only a few months, promising to reduce its size and rein in its excesses. After he left, it bounced back under a new name.

multimedia.caption: Vadim V. Bakatin in August 1991, shortly after being named head of the K.G.B., the feared Soviet spy agency. During his brief term at the agency’s helm, he tried to defang it.

title: Militants Storm Hotel in Somalia, Leaving More Than 10 Dead
abstract: The attack was the first major outbreak of violence in Mogadishu, the country’s capital, since the election of a new president in May. The insurgent group Al Shabab claimed responsibility.

multimedia.caption: Security officers patrolling in Mogadishu, Somalia, on Saturday. The hotel assault comes as the country undergoes a delicate political transition and grapples with severe drought and a humanitarian crisis.
multimedia.copyright: Hassan Ali Elmi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
